dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: 1 which reads: "There is but one temple in the Universe and that is the human body. We touch heaven when we lay our hand on it. Thomas Carlyle, 1840"

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 2 EXT. PACIFIC COAST HIGHWAY вЂ” HIGH ANGLE вЂ” DAY 2 A God's-eye view of a long, winding stream of traffic, curling along the coastline, wrapping itself around the Santa Monica Mountains, flowing north to who can say wher Somewhere in the middle of it all, little more than a droplet in the stream, is a CADILLAC ALLANTE CONVERTIBLE with its top down.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 3 I./E. CADILLAC ALLANTE вЂ” MOVING вЂ” DAY 3 As the California sun beats brilliantly down, as the rush of wind eddies and swirls inside the car, we take our pla directly behind the driver. From here, other than moment, we blown hair who she is there is little to be learned about the driver the obvious fact that she is a woman. For a see nothing of the world other than her windbillowing and and why we are traveling with her only deepens. Then, abruptly, VARIOUS CUTS of her hands on the wheel, o the speedometer, of her hand on the stickshift, etc. Occasionally, we sweep up to the mountains or down to the ocean or past the fence of some tony piece of real estate overlooking the water. But, always, we return to our poin of departure вЂ” behind the driver speeding up the Pacifi Coast Highway.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: 4  2. 5 EXT. COUNTRY ROAD вЂ” DAY 5 The Cadillac Allante rolls silently toward us before turning into a driveway that leads up the hill to a contemporary house.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 6 EXT. CONTEMPORARY HOUSE вЂ” DAY 6 Pitched on a rolling hillside more evocative of Provence than Malibu is the dramatic, sharply angular two-story wi its eclectic exterior mix of corrugated walls and mirrore glass. As Allante approaches on the driveway, we begin to sense something slightly askew about this house and this place, and not all of it has to do with architecture.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 7 EXT. ALLANTE вЂ” DAY 7 The driver's door opens and out swivels NINA: 38 years ol bright, attractive. But more than merely intelligent, she is shrewd; more than simply beautiful, she is alluring. And, perhaps, more to the point, she is shy about neither So one senses power as she rises out of the car, just as one senses insight as she takes a long, penetrating look around, just as one sees poise and grace as she glides toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 8 NINA вЂ” MOVING 8 from the car ... up the walkway ... up to the front door with the mirrored glass. She slips her key into the lock without so much as a glance at her reflected image.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 9 INT. CONTEMPORARY HOUSE вЂ” DAY 9 From the dramatic slope of the roof to the exposed rafter to the open, loft-like rooms seemingly suspended in space this house has been designed with an eclectic vengeance. Tasteful, mind you. But nonetheless a conspicuous scheme, a captivating diversion for the restless eye. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 9 All this has long ago ceased to impress Nina, who immediately ducks inside the BEDROOM to her right and sli off her shoes before continuing barefoot down the HALLWAY The day's mail awaits her, stacked tidily on a chest midw down the hall. Taking the mail in hand, she begins sortin through it even as she ascends the short staircase to the MAIN ENTERTAINING AREA of the house. There she stands, in the middle of the floor, absorbed in some letter or other, when footsteps come quickly down a staircase and DEE DEE appears. Dee Dee, a very young, very eager, very uncertain 24-year Nina, who looks up coolly from her letter.

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: (painfully self-conscious, perhaps with a frantic glance at her watch) You're home? (suddenly talking to herself) Great, Dee'D. (just as suddenly talking to Nina again) I mean, there you are, standing right in front of me.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (doing nothing to put her at ease) Hello, Dee Dee.

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: Hi, Nina. A few tentative steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Very pleasant вЂ” in a grim sort of way. As Nina returns to her letter, Dee Dee moves quickly into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 INT. KITCHEN вЂ” DAY 10 From a bucket of ice, Dee Dee removes a chilling bottle o white wine and pours a glass.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 11 INT. ENTERTAINMENT AREA вЂ” DAY 11 Dee Dee now appears with a glass of wine, which Nina take from her. With the wine glass in one hand and her mail in the other, Nina sprawls leisurely on a sofa.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: And how were things around here? But before Dee Dee can utter even syllable, Nina cuts her off.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Oh, did that what's-his-name, the strange bald lawyer call?

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: How about Douglas вЂ” did he reconfirm for this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: No, no one called.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: If he ever does call me here, it's fine to give the number for the car вЂ” the lawyer. He represents Merkey, the artist I'm showing next month. Douglas already has the number. Which must mean he's still coming вЂ” if he didn't call.

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: (not knowing if this requires a response) Well, yeah. Nina looks up: nothing like a response was either expecte or desired. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (back into the mail) So?

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: How were things around here? were about to say? You

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: The gardener came.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: And how is Mr. Li?

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: He cleared out that underbrush, where you asked about.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: Did the deep-root fertilization, too. Dee Dee hovers a little too near the sofa, prompting Nina to gaze up at her expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: I paid all the bills, the checks are on your desk, you just have to sign them. And I bought some haddock from the fishman this morning, I made a curry sauce to go with it, all you have to do is pop it in the oven, I left the directions.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: And you'd like to go home now. Dee Dee nods sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Go. Dee Dee crosses slowly to the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: Mr. Li said he won't be back again for three weeks. He has to go to (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DEE DEE (cont'd) Taiwan, I think he was trying to tell me. Some family thing.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: No doubt.

dialogues.speaker: DEE DEE
dialogues.text: He wanted to know if you wanted his nephew to come the next two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: And you told him yes, I hope. Dee Dee nods.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You're a good little wife, Dee Dee. Every woman should have one. Taking this as a compliment, she smiles and disappears. After a moment, the front door opens and closes. After a moment more, Nina rises with wine glass in hand and goes the BACK DOOR. She gazes pensively through the glass, perhaps watching Dee Dee go, perhaps not.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: 12 which reads: "Preparation The goal of the massage is to relax all the senses. Prepare with this in mind."

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 13 INT. HOUSE вЂ” DAY 13 Nina slips a CD into the compact disc player, and we hear the first, deep, barely audible bars of Albinoni's Adagio in G-Minor. As the music continues ethereally UNDER, we:

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 14 INT. BEDROOM DRESSING CLOSET вЂ” DAY 14 Standing in front of a full-length mirror, Nina takes a moment to study herself in her suit, her uniform, if you will. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a moment, after drinking off a little too much wine for one sip, she puts the glass to one side. Then, withou taking her eyes off herself, she begins removing her clothes. It is a slow and sultry dance, and her eyes, rapt hypnotically, never leave the mirror as she slides out of her skirt ... her blouse ... her nylons ... her bra.... Only gradually does it occur to us that there may be something other than prurience at stake here. This strip is not a tease but a conscious peeling away of layer upon layer of her well-ordered, well-practiced life. If she stares, it's only because she is making certain that absolutely nothing of her accustomed life is left. Once all her clothes are off, she takes another moment to study herself. Then, after retrieving a robe from an adjoining bathroom, she starts into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 15 EXT. HOUSE вЂ” JACUZZI вЂ” DAY 15 She tests the steaming, bubbling water with the graze of foot. Then, dropping her robe, she eases her body down, penetrating the water until she is submerged to the neck. Allowing her head to fall gently back, she gazes heavenwa at the starry night. She is drifting now; her mind is soaring across space and time.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 16 INT. BATHROOM вЂ” DAY 16 Standing in the shower, allowing the water to cascade ove him, is a handsome, rugged man in his middle 20s, a man w will later come to know as DOUGLAS.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: 17 still in the jacuzzi, still gazing heavenward, still drifting.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 18 EXT. STREET вЂ” IN FRONT OF THE CONTEMPORARY HOUSE вЂ” DA Turning into the driveway is a SMALL, UNASSUMING CAR вЂ” Yugo, perhaps вЂ” the sort of car that must have always (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: looked as rickety as it does now, even rolling off the assembly line.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 19 EXT. JACUZZI вЂ” DAY 19 So far adrift is Nina that it takes her a moment to reali that the car is pulling up the driveway. But when she finally does see the car, she inches forward curiously. As she watches the car disappear around the front of the house, she reaches for her robe and climbs out of the jacuzzi.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 20 EXT. DRIVEWAY вЂ” DAY 20 As he slides out from behind the wheel and unbends himsel onto the driveway, we get our first clear look at FITCH. At 44, he seems to be in equal parts showing his age and hiding it. Yes, his face is deeply lined. Yes, he is as grey as he is not. Yet, at the same time, he is as lean and agile as he was 20 years earlier. With hair that seems a day or two shy of its next trim an clothing that is вЂ” in a word вЂ” utilitarian, he resemb nothing so much as the publisher of a natural foods catalogue. From his place by the car, he eyes the house for a moment Then, pushing forward the driver's seat, he leans in and dislodges a long, rectangular object (his unassembled, portable massage table) that is wedged diagonally across the interior of the car. Along with the massage table, he pulls out what used to b known as a "gym bag." He then glances at his watch, locks the driver's door, and with massage table and bag in hand circles around to the sidewalk leading up to the house.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 21 INT. HOUSE вЂ” DAY 21 Nina moves quickly down the HALLWAY, tying her robe as sh goes. When she reaches the end, she ducks into the BEDROO and goes to a window for a better look.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: 25 26 EXT. HOUSE вЂ” WALKWAY вЂ” DAY 26 Fitch walks deliberately toward the house, his eyes surveying the exterior, the corrugated walls, the impenetrable mirrored-glass windows.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 27 FITCH вЂ” MOVING 27 toward ANOTHER HOUSE: small, rural, eerily still, the perfect setting for вЂ” well, who can say just what?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 28 EXT. HOUSE вЂ” AS BEFORE вЂ” DAY 28 When Fitch reaches the front steps, he removes a business card (not his own) and matches the hand-written name scrawled on the back of it with the name by the door. He takes another look at his watch then presses a button on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 29 INT. HOUSE вЂ” HOME ENTERTAINMENT CENTER вЂ” DAY 29 With the push of a button, Albinoni falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 30 INT. HOUSE вЂ” FRONT DOOR вЂ” DAY Nina opens the blinds and peers curiously. was expecting, Fitch is obviously not he. 30 Whomever she

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 31 EXT. FRONT DOOR вЂ” DAY 31 Fitch stands in front of the mirror-glass, seeing absolutely nothing of Nina, glancing inadvertently at his reflected image, perhaps adjusting his hair slightly when he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 INT. FRONT DOOR вЂ” DAY 32 She peers at him a moment longer, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (through the door) Hi. She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (eyeing him with suspicion) Yes? I'm Fitch.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Fitch.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Fitch?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I'm here for your appointment. As if to introduce some physical evidence in his defense, he points to the portable massage table at his side.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Where's Douglas?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Didn't he call you? He said he was вЂ” he would вЂ” call you. He didn't call you.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: To tell me what?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: That he couldn't make it.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Douglas?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: He said. It's difficult to tell which has Nina puzzled more: Fitch presence or his appearance. Whoever the much talked about (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Douglas is, he definitely doesn't wear Birkenstock sandal With sox. Nina then takes an absent-minded step back, giving the impression вЂ” more or less unintended вЂ” that she would Fitch to come right in. Without giving it a second thought, he squeezes by her in the house. And so he's well inside before she even realizes what has happened.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: So where would you like me to set up, Nina? Without waiting for a response, Fitch starts for the adjoining bedroom, but Nina intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: We're usually this way. She extends a hand, indicating the end of the hallway is their intended direction of travel. With a bemused shake of the head, Nina closes the front door and follows.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: 33 34 INT. HALLWAY вЂ” DAY 34 As she closes the door, Fitch confidently walks to the en of the hallway and turns into the large, open studio. Seeing him disappear, she takes off after him.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: 35 36 INT. STUDIO вЂ” DAY 36 Fitch is already in the middle of the room by the time Ni appears in the doorway. He puts his massage items to one side and begins to wander curiously through the room, examining things that he comes across.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Where is he, do you know?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Who? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Didn't come up. He picks up a book that he finds lying on a table. crosses to him and takes it from him. She

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: "The Sun Also Rises."

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I liked it. A brief beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You see, I'm really very ... accustomed to him вЂ” Douglas. Fitch nods a small, noncommittal nod.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I like him.... Fitch nods again.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I really like him.... Fitch nods yet again.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: And it takes time вЂ” for a woman, at least вЂ” it takes time getting comfortable, really comfortable with a man who's ... She doesnвЂ™t finish her thought.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Doug's got the touch. He pulls open a sliding glass door that leads out to the deck. He steps outside. After a moment, she follows.

dialogues.speaker: THE DECK
dialogues.text: 37 as Fitch appears at her side. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: But without even picking up the phone or ...? Fitch peers at her, having temporarily lost the train of thought.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Douglas. When you have a relationship with someone вЂ” a business relationship вЂ” we go back, he and I вЂ” you expect some consideration.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: He seemed to be in a rush. young. He's very

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: He's not so terribly young.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: No, not so. But he is young. A lot younger than he thinks he is, anyway. Besides, he could have not called either one of us. A beat, as he walks farther onto the deck, drinking in th surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: He's very talented.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: He is. Good-looking kid, too. Women seem to go for him. A lot of his clients are women. Most, really. At this, she says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Outside's nice. Especially if you have some privacy. And you have some privacy.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Douglas does me outside.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: A little cold tonight.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Where would you suggest then? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Some dark and quiet place. She nods her head.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: You know, I was in such a hurry getting over here. I've got my oils and things, but sheets and towels ... She nods then they steps back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I left some stuff in the car.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 38 INT. HOUSE вЂ” UPSTAIRS вЂ” DAY 38 Nina opens a linen closet, removes the sheets and towels that Fitch has asked for, then closes the closet door.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 39 EXT. FITCH'S CAR вЂ” DAY 39 He removes another small bag or two from the car then closes the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 40 INT. STUDIO вЂ” DAY 40 When Nina comes back, however, Fitch is nowhere to be see

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 41 INT. HOUSE вЂ” HALLWAY вЂ” DAY 41 Walking out of the studio, she sees the massage table jus where he left it: still leaning against a wall, still not set up. Now, a little curious вЂ” perhaps even a little concerned she starts out of the room in search of Fitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 NINA вЂ” MOVING 42 through the house, picking up speed, until she at last walks into a bedroom where she discovers Fitch, examining some jewelry that is scattered across the top of a dresse

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: 43 as Fitch turns to see Nina, eyes locked on him, coming closer. Without the slightest hesitation, he resumes studying the diamond bracelet that he spreads across his palm.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I'm fascinated with things. That is, I'm fascinated with the fascination with things.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: This is my bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I thought it might be. My mother had a spectacular jewelry collection, as I recall. A dubious beat, as she wonders just what he may be up to.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (sensing her distrust) I wanted to wash up. And when I happened to walk by ... She hands over the sheets and towels, which forces him to hand over the bracelet.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted to wash up. She leads him into the bathroom, which we recognize as th one that Doug was showering in earlier.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: 44 which reads: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "The Massage Table The table should be tall enough to elevate the subject to a comfortable height."

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 45 INT. HOUSE вЂ” STUDIO вЂ” DAY 45 From a chair, Nina looks on as Fitch goes about the ritua of setting up his massage table. And it is just that: a ritual. Each piece, each bolt, each nut and washer, he assembles with devotion and ceremony, all of it perhaps a unconscious as not.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: What massage is about in the end is healing. There are ways people can heal without drugs or words or prayers. That's it; that's the essence.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I never really gave it much thought.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Healing?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Massage вЂ” in those terms. I try not to intellectualize things too much. It makes life so grey. I'm more ... intuitive, I think. She watches as Fitch again immerses himself in his ritual then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (smiling) Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I don't know, why not ask? I mean, you never learn anything without asking, do you?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (still smiling) Older than you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She is now staring at him, as we:

dialogues.speaker: A PARK-LIKE PLACE
dialogues.text: 46 where a BEARDED MAN, approximately Fitch's age, assembles an easel with the same sense of ritual and attention. The man looks up when we hear:

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) The laying on of hands вЂ” there's power in it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 47 THE SUN ROOM вЂ” AS BEFORE 47 Fitch looks up briefly from his work, seeing her staring him. But, clearly, he doesn't give it a second thought as he once more focuses his attention on the table.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: But, in our culture, there are so many Western prejudices about illness and healing. We're really pretty tight-assed, medically speaking. Just think about it: when was the last time your doctor actually touched you? not probed or examined but touched you?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: If it never happened, it was too recent. I don't like doctors вЂ” mine or anyone else's.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Because they consult with you, they talk with you over the phone, they prescribe drugs for you. But they don't actually вЂ” personally вЂ” heal you. They leave that up to time or chemistry.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I don't like doctors because ... I don't like doctors. A beat, then: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You've known Doug for how long? Fitch shrugs: Doug is a topic of conversation that he can either take or leave. And right now he feels more like leaving it than taking it.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Long enough to like him?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: How long's that? (beat) It goes back to the ancients, you know.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Massage. Maybe even earlier, some historians think. The Greeks were into massage mainly as a treatment, a healing art. They've got records of people like Socrates and Plato being massaged daily. And Plato lived to be 104.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Socrates did not.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (undeterred) But the Romans being who they were вЂ” essentially Italians without the loafers вЂ” they were the first to come up with the idea of massage as a form of foreplay. Courtesans got pretty handy at it. It was part of the transaction, finally.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Well, it's not like you have to have a degree in molecular biology to see a connection. Massage is sexual. Very sexual.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: It can be. It doesn't have to be. It shouldn't always be. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I wasn't talking about sweating, screaming, orgasmic epiphany. It's just that you're lying there naked, someone's touching you in places you sure wouldn't let your father touch you, and it's ... arousing.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: It's a form of communication. You just have to make sure you're both speaking the same language. Fitch makes a few final adjustments to the table. Seeing that he is nearly finished, Nina she sheds her rob It takes a moment for her to locate a towel, during which time Fitch gets an eyeful. He says nothing. She says nothing. But neither her complete lack of embarrassment nor his utter professional disinterest strikes us as entirely authentic. Finally spotting her towel, she draws it carelessly around hersel Fitch stands up.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Looks like we're ready to start.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: We've already started.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Fitch reaches for his massage "tool bag" and begins removing items.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Well, most of any massage worth having takes place in your head. And I'm sure you've been preparing вЂ” (suddenly, a thought occurs to him) Why, are you in a hurry? Before she can reply, he pulls an extremely odd and not easily explained item out of his bag of tricks. He holds it up for her to see.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Funny thing, hunh? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He puts that item back and pulls out one or two more.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: You might want to have some music. What was that music you were playing? before you turned it off?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I'll find something. She crosses out of the room. her. After a moment, he follows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 From the doorway, Fitch watches as she climbs the stairs and goes to the stereo system. It's only when she makes her music selection and turns back that she sees him looking at her. A puzzling, slightly unsettling beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I'd say we're ready.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: 49 which reads: "The Back The back is the best place to begin any full body massage."

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 51 Nina now lies prone on the table. Fitch is, from all appearances, ready to go to work. He peels back the towel so that it doesn't quite cover her butt.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: So what are we working on, Nina? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Any complaints? maladies? any part of your body that needs special attention?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: The part that begins at my hair and ends at my toes. From his bag, he removes an impressive assortment of bottles and jars. He selects one then begins applying oil in long, slow, sweeping strokes until the whole of her ba is slick and glistening.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 52 A SERIES OF SHOTS вЂ” THE ART OF THE MASSEUR 52 Hands float ... fingers unfold ... forearms bunch ... biceps flex ... shoulders tauten ... as IN and OUT OF FRA his body glides with power and grace. Watching, we are witness to nothing short of Fitch's complete mastery of his art: he is nothing short of the Baryshnikov of massage.

dialogues.speaker: A PAIR OF HANDS
dialogues.text: 53 Younger. Slightly more muscular. Noticeably less accomplished. Decidedly less poetic. More ballroom than ballet. More James T. Farrell than Marcel Proust. And when the CAMERA moves slowly BACK, we see that it is not Fitch massaging Nina but the handsome, rugged man: Douglas. Every now and then, she lets out a small, involuntary sig which after a time begins to sound very much like a moan. This goes on for a moment or two, growing in intensity, until the spell is broken by:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (o.s.) It's my job, you know....

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 54 Fitch continues with warm, luxurious, circulating strokes beginning at the small of her back and flowing up to her shoulder blades.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You were going to say something about how tense I am.... Maybe he was. More likely he was undergoing some out-ofbo of her back that he massages.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Douglas always does. He's always telling me how much tension I have. Especially in my upper back, my shoulders. It's all because of my work.... A beat of expectation, as she waits for him to question h about her work. Then, when he does not, when he simply continues massaging her in intense silence, she answers anyway:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I own a gallery. A couple of them, actually. One here in town, off Melrose. Another in New York, Tribeca. And when it's your business, your baby вЂ” well, you know what they say about responsibility falling on your shoulders. It does вЂ” literally. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: It's best not to talk so much.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Was I? talking too much?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Well, it's your massage. You can do anything you'd like. But you really should take some time to relax. I mean, you can't keep going all the time. Or is that what the people you work with do? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: The people I work with limit their relaxation to what they can purchase in a vial. After he performs a series of long, deep strokes, she visibly loosens up. She seems to be taking his advice. Half-joking, he lifts one of her feet and lets it drop to the table.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Working already, see?

dialogues.speaker: THE PARK-LIKE PLACE
dialogues.text: 55 where the bearded man paints at an easel. The painting that he labors at is perhaps more naturalistic than what fashionable these days. The work is nevertheless accomplished. Just then, Nina drives by in her CAR. For some reason, th sight of the man at his easel captures her imagination. She makes a u-turn and drives back. After a moment, she is out of the car and over his shoulder. He turns, surprised to see anyone anywhere near him. She continues studying the painting, even as he studies her.

dialogues.speaker: PAINTER
dialogues.text: (as he continues painting) So what do you think of it? Nina gives an approving nod of the head.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 56 After a brief, contempative beat вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: How long have you been doing massage, Fitch?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Almost 20 years вЂ” off and on.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Interesting work. I'm sure you meet all kinds of people. Gives you a lot (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NINA (cont'd) of freedom, too, I bet. I mean, it's so portable: have table, will travel.... A brief beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I travel a lot вЂ” in my work. Too much, I'm starting to think. I guess it just depends how badly you want what you want... Another brief beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Do you like art? You seem like the sort of person who does.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And what sort of person is that?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Well, an ... (catching herself) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (more musing than argumentative) Just that I never thought there was a type, that's all. But I suppose you'd know more about that than I would.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Well, do you? enjoy art?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (after a moment of consideration) Who do you consider to be the great artists of this century?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I mean who are the five greatest вЂ” or four вЂ” or three?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I'm really not in that business. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Would you say Picasso? Would he be one? Or maybe Chagall вЂ” ?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: - I don't think you can quantify artistic achievement FITCH - or would you say Braque? or Klee?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What's your point, Fitch? Instead of replying, Fitch retreats for a moment, again massaging her in silence. His strokes now become a tease although from all appearances an inadvertent one вЂ” as h hands move nearer and nearer her ass. Finally, in a series of deep, slow strokes, he slips his hands under the towel and withdraws them, then slips them under again вЂ” to which she visibly succumbs. Her eyelid close heavily.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: 57 now in Fitch's place, leaning over the massage table, as his movements more or less echo the strokes that Fitch ha just performed.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: 58 on the table as she sighs deeply.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 59 Nina emerges slowly from her reverie.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What was it you were going to say? No response.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You were going to say something and then you just stopped. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: When there is still no response, she looks up to see that Fitch is gone. Then, as she slides off the table to go in search of him, she hears a strange CLICKING sound coming from the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 60 INT. HALLWAY вЂ” DAY 60 Returning from his car, Fitch is clicking together TWO LARGE MAGNETS as he walks down the hall. Suddenly, a painting hanging on the wall catches his eye. It's about then that Nina emerges from the studio.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: This is just me now, this is just my opinion. But so much of what passes for art today вЂ” contemporary art вЂ” is without any kind of reference point: moral, historic, nothing. It's not about anything.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Oh, I disagree. Modern art is critical. That's what makes it modern.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARK-LIKE SETTING
dialogues.text: 61 The bearded painter sits at the easel preparing his palet as Nina continues to linger over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Where do you show? The painter laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 62 INT. HALLWAY вЂ” AS BEFORE 62 Nina sees the magnets.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What are those?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (deadpan) I don't know. I just found them in the trunk of my car. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks askance at him: she takes him at his word.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: They're magnets.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Magnets?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: About 400 gauss potency вЂ” perfect for those hard-to-treat areas. Without pausing to explain further, he moves into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 Nina follows Fitch in as he crosses to the stove. There, he turns on a burner and begins warming the magnets. Then, as she looks on with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You really must visit my gallery. We've got a very interesting installation coming up next month I think you should see.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And what's that?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: A history of women's fashion as a form of bondage. Fitch cocks an amused eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Come and see it. I think you'll enjoy it. It has a certain point of view. It's funny. Ironic. Satiric.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: A point of view.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Exactly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I'll tell you вЂ” and this is why so much of art today is so pointless, I think вЂ” what we suffer from, our society, is a kind of bankruptcy of spirit.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I'm sure people have said something like as long as there have been people to say it.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Except this time it's true.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I'm sure they said that, too.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 64 ALICE вЂ” CLOSE UP 64 20ish, stunning, she stares into the CAMERA, revealing le than she shows.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (v.o.) If you're talking about today вЂ” the way we live вЂ” it's fear вЂ” that's what defines us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 Fitch and Nina return: he with the magnets in hand, she a few steps behind him. Taking note the massage chair by th window, he crosses to it.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Is this yours? She nods. He indicates that she should sit in it, which she does. He then kneels before her, placing a warmed magnet beneath either of her feet.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Fear of change. Fear of the future. Technology transforming things faster than people can take in. It turns us into strangers, everyone. That's why people create the art they create. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Bad faith.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Blaming someone else вЂ” something else вЂ” technology вЂ” as if we had no responsibility for ourselves, our actions.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: So what would you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I suggest we look inward, all of us, for starters. And then, I suggest we look outward.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: And then do we all sit cross-legged on the floor, humming like gnats?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: We might. We could. Why not? Or else we could just go out and kill all the gallery owners. A beat, as Nina, amused, smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: 66 which reads: "The Neck and Shoulders Neck tension is often the root of psychological fatigue."

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE CHAIR
dialogues.text: 67 Fitch now glides his hands along her spine up to her neck and shoulders. He begins to apply acupressure in a series of short, powerful bursts. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The power of his fingertips causes her to exhale audibly she tries to diffuse the discomfort through her breathing Hearing this, he doesn't stop. Nor does she ask him to.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE CHAIR
dialogues.text: 68 where Douglas has once more replaced Fitch. The discomfor that he causes, however, plainly borders on pain, resembling nothing so much as controlled violence. Yet, the harder he massages her, the more she grunts and groans and gasps for breath and вЂ” from all indications just generally enjoys herself.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH AND NINA
dialogues.text: 69 Although Fitch continues his acupressure strong and hard, the mood вЂ” in contrast to Nina and Douglas вЂ” seems downright pacific.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Do you have any family, Fitch? Wife, children? Fitch shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Mother, father?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Gone now. They've been dead a while. I have a sister back in Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I try to stay close to my family. It's important, don't you think? My sister's in Boston, my brother's in Georgia somewhere, my parents are retired in Florida, but we work at it. It's important. Don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE CHAIR
dialogues.text: 70 Fitch lets his eyes close, shutting out the world, as his fingertips insinuate themselves into her flesh.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 71 FITCH вЂ” MOVING 71 toward the small, rural house, his eyes fixed on the fron door.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (v.o.) What makes you think that?

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE CHAIR
dialogues.text: 72 Fitch's eyes remain closed for a moment or two.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Think what?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: A "bankruptcy of spirit" вЂ” is that really what we're about?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Call it what you like. The essence is that we've lost our way. As a civilization. Spiritually, I'm saying. I've been around, and one thing I've learned: we don't know what we don't know. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: My work, I suppose, has a spiritual side to it.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARK-LIKE PLACE
dialogues.text: 73 Still seated at the easel, still laughing, the painter turns slightly so that he faces Nina. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAINTER
dialogues.text: Where do I show?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 74 NINA IN THE CHAIR вЂ” AS BEFORE 74

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Each artist is unique.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 75 THE PARK-LIKE PLACE вЂ” AS BEFORE 75

dialogues.speaker: PAINTER
dialogues.text: People like me don't show anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 76 NINA IN THE CHAIR вЂ” AS BEFORE 76

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Each has individual needs.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 77 THE PARK-LIKE PLACE вЂ” AS BEFORE 77 The painter turns back toward the easel.

dialogues.speaker: PAINTER
dialogues.text: I'm not in fashion.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE CHAIR
dialogues.text: 78 Fitch kneels again and removes the magnets from beneath h feet.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Although there is the matter of compensation.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: People understand that when they come to me. Usually, that's why they come to me. Artists are rarely as troubled by the idea of their earning a living as everyone else seems to be. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (puzzled) So, then, what's the spiritual side to your work? But before she can respond, the strength of his acupressu her to exhale hoarsely suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (as he persists in applying pressure) This isn't too hard for you, Nina?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (breathless) Why do you ask? Fitch lays off on the acupressure, smoothing over the are with lush, soothing strokes.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I had aspirations, artistic aspirations. Except that I saw myself up onstage somewhere, a performer. Only problem was I couldn't sing or dance. I could audition. I mean, my gift is I know how to sell and so I sold myself. And in rehearsal, come to think of it, I was okay, passable.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Would I have ever seen you in anything?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: No. Lucky man. She laughs at this. But if what she says is an exaggeration, there clearly remains some element of truth to it.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: It was in school, mostly. But once or twice, in an otherwise professional theatre, I actually got up in front of a paying audience ... and made them pay.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (amused) So how'd the gallery business get you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Oh, the same way most people end up doing things. I fell in love with the wrong person.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Artist?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Artist, art dealer, art critic вЂ” he was all artistic things to all artistic people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 ANDY вЂ” swaggering, 40ish, slightly scuzzy in a bohemian вЂ” peers into CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: NINA AND FITCH
dialogues.text: 80 as he leads her from the massage chair back to the massag table.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And what happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Who can say really?

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: 81 which reads: "The Feet Because there is less flesh to work with, care must be taken not to probe too deeply."

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 82 Standing at the lower end of the table, Fitch drenches he feet in oil.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: 83 as he strokes her feet.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: 84 as she slackens her mind and allows it to roam.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 85 DOUGLAS вЂ” AS BEFORE 85 stroking her feet, kneading them, tugging at them, all wi unrelieved dispassion.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH AND NINA
dialogues.text: 86 In contrast, Fitch's contact with her strikes us as far more sexual вЂ” superficially, at least вЂ” than Douglas' But appearances can, as they say, be deceiving. For as erotic as this foot massage may seem, it is, for Fitch, far more transcendental than sexual. Once more, hi eyes close, his mind soars, and his hands seem to assume will and intelligence of their own.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 87 FITCH вЂ” MOVING 87 to the front of the small, RURAL HOUSE. Just as he is about to knock on the door, it opens slowly on its own. H peers inside. Not another person in sight, even when the door has opened all the way.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 88 With Fitch continuing to stroke her feet, Nina is very nearly purring вЂ” until she is jarred back to reality by own hyperactive intellect:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I like what I do, where I've ended up, who I am. It gives me an enormous amount of satisfaction. A brief beat, then: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Are you happy, Fitch?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Happy?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You said you've spent all this time traveling around. I was just wondering if it made you happy.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: It's made me a better person. Sure. I suppose. Happier than most people. If that's what it's about. Nina seems puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: There's more to happiness than being happy.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Meaning what? Suddenly, we are back into the foot massage, with it near We take a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: You see, with most people вЂ” cultures вЂ” civilizations вЂ” this idea of happiness вЂ” it's not some frivolous thing. It's not a good job. It's not a new car in the driveway. It's something else entirely.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Something spiritual.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (with a reflexive nod) The Hopi Indians believe the body of a person and the earth are formed in the same way: along an axis. Fitch gives up her feet for a moment and glides his hand upward along her legs until he reaches her spine, which h then gently massages. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: The axis for you and me is our backbone, our spine. And along this axis are various centers of force NINA Centers of force?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 89 EXT. CAMPFIRE вЂ” NIGHT 89 A Hopi shaman massages a woman by the firelight.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) They're all very important, these different body centers: the brain, the throat, the solar plexus. But the most important of all is the heart. Follow its sincere purpose, the Hopis say, and you're of one heart. But if you allow evil feelings to enter, they say you are of two hearts. ....

dialogues.speaker: NINA AND FITCH
dialogues.text: 90 With his hand reaching under her belly, resting below her solar plexus, he pauses for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: It all sounds very ... Eastern. Fitch withdraws his hand and takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Well, it is, in a way.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: The Tibetans and Hindus believed in an almost identical series of centers in the body.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (smug) It's like some shared subconscious. Almost like people are programmed to invent them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Almost. A beat, as he sizes her up, wondering if she has even an inkling as to what he's been saying. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Now to me, personally, the most interesting part of this is how the Hopi medicine man takes these centers of force and treats someone.

dialogues.speaker: A DOUBLE BED
dialogues.text: 91 Fitch lies on his back as the young woman ALICE lays her hands upon him. He listens intently, rapt by the words sh speaks, the lesson she teaches. For if Fitch is a student of the Hopi culture, this may very well be his first lesson.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You see, he can tell what's wrong with just his hands. He can feel the vibrations from each center and find in which one life runs strongest or weakest.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 92 as Fitch continues the laying on of hands.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Sometimes what's wrong is what you'd call illness. But other times, it comes from outside, drawn by a person's own evil thoughts or from those of a Two Heart.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOUBLE BED
dialogues.text: 93 as the woman continues instructing.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Then, the medicine man will take a small crystal about an inch and a (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ALICE (cont'd) half across and look through it at each of the centers.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 94 as Fitch continues searching the centers of force.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And that way, he can see the source of the trouble and, the Hopis say, the actual face of the Two Hearts who's causing it. A beat, then Fitch returns his hands to Nina's feet and resumes massaging them.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (mocking) Tell me you've got a crystal in that bag of yours.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (with an unamused laugh) No.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Because I could stand to know which Two Hearts are causing me my pain. Fitch is visibly annoyed, noticeably tired of humoring he smugness. He wanders away from the table.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: It works, though, you know, this kind of healing. What we forget is modern medicine вЂ” any science when you think about it вЂ” is a belief system: a religion like any other religion. Medicine works because we believe it will work.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Sometimes it just works.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And lots of times it doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I like clergymen even less than doctors. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: That's because you worship in the temple of Art. Which is a whole lot like the temple of Science, when you get right down to it. Your God is a jealous God вЂ” the most jealous God of all, in fact вЂ” the God of Reason.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I see. So you're suggesting вЂ” what? вЂ” I convert? Become a Hopi mystic? Can you do that, by the way? Convert to another race?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: The point I was making, really, is that we have вЂ” without even realizing it вЂ” given up one kind of mysticism for another, more socially acceptable form of mysticism. I don't know about you, but I've never seen a black hole or a quark. They may exist; they may not; I personally have no way of knowing. I have seen Hopis walk away healed, though, by nothing more than a medicine man using his hands and a few crystals.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Christ, you're patronizing.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: All I'm saying is we вЂ” everyone вЂ” we've gone and replaced a system of belief with a system of disbelief. And that it's found its way into everything we do and think. We've lost the capacity for wonder. And no one вЂ” and this is the insidious part вЂ” no one even knows that it's happened.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Except you. Fitch is plainly taken aback. Abruptly, we:

dialogues.speaker: THE DOUBLE BED
dialogues.text: 95 Alice kneels in the middle of the bed while she continues touching Fitch ritualistically.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: They understand themselves, the Hopis.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 96 THE MASSAGE TABLE вЂ” AS BEFORE 96 Fitch takes a moment to regroup, then:

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: They understand themselves, the Hopis.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: 97 which reads: "The Back of the Leg The abundance of flesh here requires more penetrating movements."

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 98 Almost like a flashy bartender mixing a drink, Fitch pour a thick stream of oil into the palm of his hand then spreads it over her right calf and the back of her right thigh. A beat, as Nina wonders to herself if, perhaps, she hasn' been a little too callous, a little too cavalier about hi hard-won beliefs. And so:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Where have you been, Fitch? in your travels?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: More places than I can sometimes remember. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: For example.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Pretty much wherever the spirit took me. The Far East, Africa. A year with the aborigines in Australia.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Massaged your way from one end of the world to the other? He nods.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I envy that.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Traveling the world?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Having no responsibilities.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: No responsibilities? I think it's jus the opposite.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Why did you come here tonight, Fitch?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't I?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: The Far East, Africa, the Aborigines вЂ” I'm not your style. Doug asked me to. different.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: He said you were

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (pleased) Did he? (extremely pleased) I like him.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: He said, of all the people he knew, you were the one who was most ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Adrift. A beat, as she considers that, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Adrift?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: That was his word.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Why would he say that?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Doug's got the touch. Another beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What do you suppose that means? adrift? Fitch takes this as a rhetorical question until вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I mean ... what does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Your heart, your spirit вЂ” you're searching.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: How would he know? He's a kid.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Not as much of a kid as he thinks he is.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: All my life, it's been the same thing: men refusing to see me for who I am, projecting their idea of who I should be on me instead. Now, even the guy does my massages wants me to be something I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And what's that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: The tormented, career-obsessed woman. I mean, why not take a little bit of a risk and get to know someone on a more complex level? I really thought more of Douglas вЂ” I know he's your friend вЂ” but I really thought more of him.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: So it's a risk? He guides her off the table, which seems to surprise her.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What? As she looks on curiously, he pours oil across the top of the table and begins working it in like a Japanese steak chef.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Complexity. She seems not to understand.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Just now, you said he wouldn't risk knowing you on a more complex level. So: is complexity dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: You said it was.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: It is. Getting to know someone is always a risk.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: In every way, in every conceivable way.

dialogues.speaker: NINA'S SITTING ROOM
dialogues.text: 99 The painter studies A PAINTING HANGING ON THE WALL as Nin eases INTO VIEW. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What do you think? I just got it.

dialogues.speaker: PAINTER
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter what I think.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) I'm not sure I get it.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 100 From his bag he removes a yellow cloth, which he lays across the table. He then guides her back onto to it.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Intimacy вЂ” whether it's emotional or intellectual or sexual вЂ” I think it can be very threatening.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Or a risk? Threatening? Semantics?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: No, I'm trying to understand you. You said Doug didn't. So I'm trying to. He covers her with other colored cloths.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: That's what these are for. Colors draw things out of you вЂ” even in silence.

dialogues.speaker: THE PAINTING ON A WALL
dialogues.text: 101 studied by Nina and the painter.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Why doesn't it matter вЂ” what you think? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAINTER
dialogues.text: There's only one reason to do art: it needs to be done. And he did it. So why discuss it?

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 102 as Nina's mind races.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: It is a fundamental difference between men and women.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: The level of intimacy they're willing to give themselves up to. And I mean any relationship, not just a sexual вЂ” romantic вЂ” one....

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And you base that on...?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Well, I'm just not sure there is this huge difference. I haven't seen it, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You are trying to get a rise out of me? Does it sound it? to.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: It's like that old thing we used to debate: of what drives a man after sex, whether it's nature or nurture that makes him want to run for the door while the woman will lie there forever. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And that's it? That's the difference? The etiquette of sex with a stranger?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I never said anything about strangers.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Well, as much as he might be tempted, I don't think a man's going to bolt for the door the minute he's had sex with his wife.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Obviously, you don't know the same men I do.

dialogues.speaker: FLEA-RIDDEN BED
dialogues.text: 103 in some artist's garret. Andy is sprawled across the bed, chewing pensively on the end of a cigarette, when a youngish Nina approaches. Looming above him, she offers a look of great longing as she caresses herself. A brief beat, then he smirks derisively.

dialogues.speaker: NINA AND FITCH
dialogues.text: 104 as he now massages her inner thigh, plucking the flesh there.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What a man wants is an illusion: of what a woman is, of what a man and a woman are together.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Any less of an illusion, your idea?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: That all men are alike, that I'm exactly the same as Douglas, he's exactly the same as (CONTINUED)  104 48. 104

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (quickly cutting him off) All men are alike. In certain fundamental respects. I speak from experience: two bad marriages вЂ” count 'em вЂ” before I was 27. There are some variations, but they don't amount to much. She lies contemplatively for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Except maybe ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 Nina and the painter lie in bed together, aprГЁs-sex.

dialogues.speaker: PAINTER
dialogues.text: I want you to sit for me. I want you to see yourself the way I see you.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 106 A beat, as fleeting as it is wistful, then:

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Except maybe what?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Nothing. Fitch removes the colored clothes and begins to cover her up with the towel.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You really don't have to bother with that, you know.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: With what?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: The towel. Covering up. I'm not very modest, I'm afraid. I actually prefer nothing on. That's the way Douglas always does it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: He can get away with it.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Get away with it, how?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Being gay.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Gay?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Doug.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 108 where the idea of Doug's sexual preference leaves her thunderstruck, although she tries her hardest to conceal it.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: You knew he was gay?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (lying) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: He said you did.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Sure. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: He's usually very upfront about it.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Very upfront.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: In fact, that's how he and I met. He thought I was. Well, I'd actually worked on a friend of his who thought I was.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: You're not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (with a shake of the head) But Doug thinks everybody's gay. That's part of his charm. I actually think he's bisexual in some halfassed way. A brief beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Nevertheless.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Still.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: The towel.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: 109 which reads: "The Buttocks Begin at the pelvic bone, moving the flesh instead of your hand."

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 110 Fitch coolly strips the towel off Nina and tosses it down Reaching for a bottle of oil, he takes a moment to take h in. For the first time, he truly sees her: in sharp contrast the dowdy, doughy matron one might expect to be massaging in these tony surroundings, she is lithe and sun-bronzed. She seems to be, moreover, totally available. Which prompts us to:

dialogues.speaker: THE DOUBLE BED
dialogues.text: 111 where Fitch and Alice are wound around each other, pantin and writhing, in the sweaty depths of sexual heat.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 112 As he pours the oil into his hand, he gazes at Nina a moment more, perhaps unaware of how long and how intensel he has been staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: If you're ever interested in something a little different, you might want to try shiatsu. It's all about stimulating energy at different points in the body. No oil of any kind. Skin rarely touches skin. I've tried it.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Once. He now goes to work: first, oiling one side of her buttoc then the other; next, working in the oil with slow, glistening, voluptuous strokes.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOUBLE BED
dialogues.text: 113 where Fitch straddles Alice, applying oil to one side of her buttocks then the other in precisely the same fashion

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You're getting pretty good at this, you know. If you don't watch it, you might just spoil me.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: And if I do?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well, you're the one who's going to have to live with the consequences.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I'll risk it.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH AND NINA
dialogues.text: 114 as he keeps up the slow, voluptuous strokes. If what he does is not sexual, it's a pretty decent imititation, though neither one of them says or does anything to acknowledge it.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Tell me about your family, Fitch.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: My family?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Your family now gone.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Not much to tell.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What was your father?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Executive. Ad man. But his family had money to begin with. My mother's side, too. Not a lot, but money. Comfortable I guess is how they'd describe themselves.

dialogues.speaker: DINNER AT EIGHT
dialogues.text: 115 A TEEN VERSION OF FITCH, along with his SISTER, sits in t middle of a long table with a DISTINGUISHED, GREYING MAN AND WOMAN, his mother and father, at either end.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) They used to do things like dress for dinner every Saturday night.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 116 FITCH AND NINA вЂ” AS BEFORE 116 as the long, voluptuous strokes continue.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Sounds fun. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Sometimes, we'd have guests CUT TO: 117

dialogues.speaker: DINNER AT EIGHT
dialogues.text: 117 The three are now joined by a young, AFFLUENT-LOOKING COUPLE.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Someone from my father's agency вЂ” some client and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 118 FITCH AND NINA вЂ” AS BEFORE 118 as the long, voluptuous strokes continue.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: But, usually, it was just the family: my parents, my sister and me.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: It's funny. Talking about roles. My parents had these roles that they always seemed to ... inhabit. My father was the shrewd businessman. My mother was the thoughtful patron of the arts. Which was, as it turned out, a kind of fiction.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: How? Making his hands broad, he massages all over her buttocks in big, circular strokes.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Well, it was all the same to her. Classical music. Classical art. Didn't matter who or what it was. It was all lovely. The woman вЂ” and over the years I've come to almost admire this about her вЂ” she didn't have a critical bone in her body. She was the sort of person they created public television for. He tries to lose himself in the rhythm of his movements, the strokes he performs deep into her buttocks. But it doesn't work. Not this time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: One night вЂ” it was one of these Saturday night deals and some very important client was coming.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 119 TEEN FITCH вЂ” MOVING 119 down a staircase.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) The men were all going to be in black tie. And about ten minutes before the guests were supposed to arrive, I came downstairs, dressed, ready.

dialogues.speaker: THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: 120 where Teen Fitch and his father, both dressed for dinner, meet.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) My father took one look at me and вЂ” well, he wasn't pleased, let's say that.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Why?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) It was my bow tie. He said that by wearing one of those clip-on bow ties I was humiliating him beyond humiliation....

dialogues.speaker: FITCH'S FATHER
dialogues.text: 121 as he mouths the words Fitch speaks OVER. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) "A real gentleman ties his own tie," he said. "You look like a busboy."

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 122 as Fitch wanders toward the window and looks out. Nice.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: And how old were you?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Seventeen. But he wasn't ranting, you have to understand. Never.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: So what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I pulled apart the tie.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: TEEN FITCH AND HIS FATHER
dialogues.text: 123 Teen Fitch, much to his father's astonishment, pulls apar the bow.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Because it wasn't a clip-on tie. It was your standard, J. Press bow tie. But I'd tied it so well, I'd done the tie so perfectly, that it looked too good.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (v.o.) And what did he do then?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Told me to retie it. M.O.S.: Fitch's father mouths words: "Retie it." Teen Fitch, despite a brave front, appears still wounded from (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: his earlier treatment. "Retie it." His father repeats his order:

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 124 as Fitch stares into some distant place.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: That's it. Using bunched fingertips, he begins to probe deeply into the muscles over the hip joint.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: No apologies or вЂ” and you weren't angry?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Not at all?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: It wasn't about anger.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Expectations. Responsibilities. My father, my mother вЂ” they were trapped. Trapped by responsibilities to things they never thought twice about. Trapped by their own expectations of themselves. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I don't know anyone who doesn't feel some sort of ambivalence toward their parents. They are who they are, you are who they are, but then again you're not.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: But I wasn't ambivalent about them, not at all. I liked them. I totally (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FITCH (cont'd) accepted who they were вЂ” maybe even more than they did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 125 In the shallow water, Fitch massages Alice using techniqu from watsu, a kind of water massage.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The angels keep their ancient places, Turn but a stone and start a wing!

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh, some lines from a poem I once knew. Funny thing to suddenly remember.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 126 THE MASSAGE TABLE вЂ” AS BEFORE 126 Nina's eyes are now wide: she is not so much shocked by this physical intimacy as by the realization of her openness to it. Fitch, for his part, seems oblivious to what he's doing and its effect on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 Fitch continues massaging. Alice then begins humming softly. The astute ear recognizes it as the folk song, "The Streets of Laredo (The Cowboy's Lament)."

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: They're the same, did you know that? The two songs вЂ” "The Streets of Laredo" and "St. James Infirmary" вЂ” they started out as the same song and over the years went in two different directions. (sings) As I walked out on the streets of Laredo ... (a different tune) I went down to the St. James Infirmary ... (speaking) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ALICE (cont'd) Out of one place can come many different things.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 128 as he continues plucking and stroking and teasing her inn thigh.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: With my family, my parents, it was more вЂ” what? вЂ” being invisible, I guess. My father was an engineer.

dialogues.speaker: NINA'S FATHER
dialogues.text: 129 smiling, perfectly happy, perhaps mugging for the CAMERA, home movie-style.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (v.o.) He invented all these things you'd never see, things that went inside huge industrial machines to make them run faster or smoother or safer.

dialogues.speaker: THE MASSAGE TABLE
dialogues.text: 130 as he continues working on her inner thigh.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: But he never owned any of his inventions; his company did. So he never made any money to speak of. And the things he created went inside other things. So no one outside that company even knew who he was. He just did his thing.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Maybe he liked it that way. Maybe he didn't want any recognition.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Everybody wants recognition.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: The Hopis have a word: pinГє'u. means, "I am I." It (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: With my mother, it was pretty much the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: NINA'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: 131 Like her father, her mother is smiling, perfectly happy, perhaps slightly more self-conscious in front of the CAMERA, home movie-style.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (v.o.) She had the only acceptable job any woman had in those days вЂ” a nurse. And a good one.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 132 THE MASSAGE TABLE вЂ” AS BEFORE 132 as Fitch works thoughtfully on her thigh.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: But like every other nurse, she was totally ignored, stepped on by any doctor she ever worked with. Another beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: It used to break my heart to see it: two people like that, as gifted as they were, as caring. I swore I wouldn't live that way....

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: 133 The scuzzy bohemian, palette in hand, is rapt at his ease in the soft amber light of late afternoon: a portrait of the artist as a not-so-young man.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (v.o.) Which is what led me to Andy, I guess. Andy was on the faculty of the art department at the college I was going to.

dialogues.speaker: NINA AND FITCH
dialogues.text: 134 Closing his eyes, Fitch continues massaging her inner thigh, searching her by sense of touch only.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: And for someone like me вЂ” eighteen, small-town girl, anonymous вЂ” it was ... liberation. It took about three years, but we did it finally вЂ” got married вЂ” my parents weren't too pleased.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: How long were you married?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Good question. Let's see. three weeks, anyway. He smiles, believing that she's joking. Two, She's not.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Well, as popular as my husband was oncampus, he was rever border.

dialogues.speaker: A DARK ALLEY
dialogues.text: 135 where Andy meets with an UNAPPETIZING NON-BOHEMIAN.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: (v.o.) And hard as it is to believe today, I didn't have a clue.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 136 NINA AND FITCH вЂ” AS BEFORE 136

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I was eighteen, nineteen, twenty years old. I was a child FITCH - eager for attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Andy was charming, but the truth is he wasn't very smart. He made one trip too many through customs.

dialogues.speaker: A HARSHLY LIGHTED WALL
dialogues.text: 137 As a UNIFORMED MAN shoves Andy up against it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 138 NINA AND FITCH вЂ” AS BEFORE 138

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: I guess I should be grateful it wasn't on our honeymoon. A thoughtful beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I did it for the attention, sure. Which can't be said about my second husband. Because I took my parents' advice after that. I settled down with a decent, honorable, hard-working young man. It was like taking a four-year nap. A brief beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: They were mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: But you learned from them.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Not really. Well, maybe. I did decide the only men you should ever seriously consider marrying are the ones who already are. For the most part, they've had some experience at it.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Let's take a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140 As Nina sits, Fitcjh prepares his Japanese acupressure heating pads.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: This is a kind of Japanese acupuncture that uses heat instead of needles. He places the pad between her thumb and index finger and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: We put it here for nervous tension. A beat, as she observes him, then:

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: How about you?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: How about me, what?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Married?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Close? I suppose. you mean.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: Maybe. Depends how close

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: A serious relationship. A "meaningful" relationship. You've had one of those, I would hope.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: I would hope. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: But nothing that stirred up the old conjugal instinct.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: An instinct? is that what it is?

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: The desire to mate вЂ” sure.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: The desire to mate is not the desire to marry.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: No, I suppose not.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: No more than standing in a firing squad is the same as standing in front of a firing squad.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: What's getting married about, anyway? Two people swept up in the most out of control, delusive kind of passion, swearing to God they'll stay that for the rest of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Oh, so you're a romantic.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH
dialogues.text: For me, what comes out of an experience isn't nearly so interesting as the experience itself.

dialogues.speaker: A CAMPFIRE
dialogues.text: 141 Fitch and the young woman stare into the fire.

dialogues.text: 203 EXT. NINA'S HOUSE вЂ” DRIVEWAY вЂ” DUSK 203 Fitch makes his way down the walkway to his car, glancing back over his shoulder as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 204 FITCH'S POV вЂ” FRONT DOOR 204 With the door open wide, Nina watches him.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 205 REVERSE POV вЂ” FITCH 205 waves, ducks into the car, and turns the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: FITCH'S CAR
dialogues.text: 206 as it pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 207 EXT./INT. HOUSE вЂ” FRONT DOOR вЂ” DUSK 207 Nina lingers a moment, watching the car disappear into th darkness, before she closes the door. When she turns away (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: from the door, something in the bedroom the room catches her eye.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 208 INT. HOUSE вЂ” BEDROOM вЂ” DUSK 208 Hanging from the wall is the PORTRAIT OF NINA that the painter painted. Nina gazes at it wistfully. She then remembers that she holds something in her hand. She looks down at the computer chip that Fitch gave her and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 209 INT. FITCH'S CAR вЂ” MOVING вЂ” DUSK 209 From the seat next to him, Fitch fumbles for a tape then inserts it into the ageing tape player. But instead of music, we hear the young woman's VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from the player) Is it on?

dialogues.speaker: FITCH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from the player) It's on. The sound of some fumbling with the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 210 ALICE вЂ” CLOSE UP 210 singing into the tape recorder's microphone.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (singing a capella) I went down to the St. James Infirmary, To see my baby there, She was stretched out on a long white table, So pale, so cold, and so fair.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 211 INT. FITCH'S CAR вЂ” MOVING вЂ” AS BEFORE вЂ” DUSK 211

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (v.o., singing) Let her go, let her go, God bless her вЂ” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fitch reaches over and turns off the tape player. He then fixes his eyes on the PACIFIC COAST HIGHWAY ahead.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: 212 213 INT. HOUSE вЂ” HALLWAY вЂ” DUSK 213 Nina now moves through the hallway, eyeing her various objets d'art, looking at them with a critical eye that seems to suggest some serious re-analysis is going on, artistic and otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 214 INT. FITCH'S CAR вЂ” MOVING вЂ” DUSK 214 As the last light of day disappears, as headlights of oncoming traffic stream uninterrupted toward us, we ride with Fitch for several moments more. 215
